diagnosis.score_summary: The brand successfully maintains its 'High Priest' mission and 'Royal' tone across channels, creating a strong cult-like foundation. However, a critical disconnect in Positioning (Price/Value) and USP (Biology vs. Technology) threatens to turn the luxury flagship site into a confusing upsell for the Amazon commodity.

truth_1.headline: The Miracle vs. The Bottle
truth_1.gap_description: WWW signals 'The Specialist' (owning the Biological Condition). PDP signals 'The Tech Engineer' (owning the Amber Glass Bottle). You are selling a medical cure on the site and a packaging feature on Amazon.
truth_1.evidence: WWW: 'The Specialist' (Scope: 5/5 Condition) vs. PDP: 'The Tech Engineer' (Ownership: 4/5 Tech)
truth_1.why_matters: When the USP shifts from 'Hormone Balance' (Site) to 'Glass Bottle' (Amazon), the product loses its magic. The customer starts buying the container, not the oil.
truth_1.the_hard_choice: You are currently split between selling a biological transformation and selling a superior shipping container. The market demands a single hero: either admit the oil is a commodity and the glass *is* the value (Option A), or demote the packaging claims on Amazon to restore the focus on the hormonal miracle (Option B). You cannot change the world if you are just selling better Tupperware.

truth_2.headline: Sanctuary vs. Snobbery
truth_2.gap_description: WWW delivers 'Relief' (Safety/Sanctuary). PDP delivers 'Intelligence' (Savvy/Validation). The site soothes a frightened patient; the marketplace strokes the ego of a smart shopper.
truth_2.why_matters: The emotional payoff is conflicting. If I buy on Amazon, I feel smart. If I buy on the site, I feel safe. This disconnect prevents deep emotional loyalty because the user doesn't know which role to play.
truth_2.the_hard_choice: You are treating the customer as a victim on your site and a genius on Amazon. This emotional volatility breaks trust. You must choose: either validate their intellect by leaning into the 'Smart Choice' narrative globally (Option A), or focus purely on the 'Safe Harbor' emotional cure (Option B). You can't be both the doctor and the debate club.

truth_3.headline: The Luxury Pricing Trap
truth_3.gap_description: WWW positions the brand as 'Scientific Miracle' (Luxury/Aspirational). PDP positions it as 'Medical Authority' (Masstige). The price signals ($75 implied vs. $37) suggest the Amazon product might be a 'lite' version.
truth_3.why_matters: The 'Practitioner Grade' claim is undermined by the cheaper Amazon reality. High-end buyers will suspect the Amazon stock is lower quality, while Amazon buyers will view the site as a rip-off.
truth_3.the_hard_choice: Your pricing architecture is telling two different stories about quality. You face a binary choice: either lower the website's 'Miracle' posturing to match the accessible reality of the marketplace (Option A), or pull the plug on the volume pricing strategy to protect the 'Royal' equity (Option B). A crown sold at a discount is just a hat.

truth_4.headline: The Neon Glitch
truth_4.gap_description: WWW introduces a 'Neon Hot Pink' accent (Entropy 3/5). PDP remains strictly 'Amber & Gold' (Entropy 2/5). The site flashes 'Trendy Pop' signals that contradict the 'Ancient Medical' vibe of the product page.
truth_4.evidence: Visual Identity: WWW (Neon Pink accents) vs. PDP (Strict Amber/Gold)
truth_4.why_matters: The 'Neon Pink' breaks the fourth wall. It signals 'Marketing' rather than 'Medicine.' It creates a subtle feeling that the 'Ancient Ritual' is actually a modern Gen-Z trend play.
truth_4.the_hard_choice: The neon pink on your site is the visual equivalent of a priest wearing sneakersâ€”it breaks the immersion. You must decide: either scrub the pop-colors to fully commit to the 'Apothecary' aesthetic (Option A), or inject the neon energy into the Amazon listings to pivot the brand toward 'Modern Wellness' (Option B). Consistency is the only path to authority.

truth_5.headline: The Practitioner Power Play
truth_5.gap_description: Both channels align on 'The High Priests' mission (100% Match). However, PDP executes this with greater ferocity using 'Practitioner Grade' and 'Naturopathic Doctor' repetitively.
truth_5.evidence: Mission Alignment: 100% (High Priests). PDP Intensity > WWW Intensity.
truth_5.why_matters: The Marketplace has proven that 'Authority' sells better than 'Royalty.' The 'Practitioner' label is doing the heavy lifting for conversion, yet the site leans more into the abstract 'Queen' metaphor.
truth_5.the_hard_choice: Your Amazon listing proves that customers want a Doctor, not a Queen. You have a clear winning strategy: either rebrand the website to lead with 'Naturopathic Medicine' and subordinate the royal metaphor (Option A), or keep the website vague and lose the conversion power of the white coat (Option B). In health, credentials beat crowns.

marker_1.so_what: The site claims power comes from the Earth (Raw Nature), while Amazon claims it comes from the Doctor (Hybrid Science). You are confusing the customer about whether this is a spiritual harvest or a clinical formulation.

marker_2.so_what: A perfect lock on the 'Cult' aspect of the brand. Both channels agree that this is a lifestyle membership for the educated elite, not just a product transaction.

marker_3.so_what: The core value is safety, but Amazon pushes 'Performance Purity' while the site pushes 'Gentle Safety.' It's a subtle drift between 'This works hard' and 'This won't hurt you.'

marker_4.so_what: This is a value perception failure. The site frames the product as an expensive investment (~$75), while Amazon frames it as an accessible staple (~$30). This creates immediate skepticism about the site's pricing.

marker_5.so_what: The brand maintains a consistent posture of 'Benevolent Superiority.' Whether as a Deity or a Specialist, the customer knows who is in charge.

marker_6.so_what: The dominant 'Ruler' energy is locked. The secondary drift between Caregiver (Site) and Sage (Amazon) means the site feels more nurturing while Amazon feels more academic.

marker_7.so_what: A strong, unified voice. The Amazon copy is slightly graver about 'plastic toxins,' but both channels effectively maintain the 'Professional Guide' persona.

marker_8.so_what: The visual world is consistent, with a minor 'Entropy' gap where the site allows for more 'Pop' energy (Neon Pink) compared to the rigid structure of the Amazon page.

marker_9.so_what: A fundamental mismatch in rhetoric. The site speaks like a Chemist describing ingredients; Amazon speaks like a Problem Solver fixing a threat (plastic). You are explaining on one channel and saving on the other.

marker_10.so_what: The story of the 'Visionary Founder' providing a 'Personal Cure' is perfectly synchronized. This narrative anchor helps stabilize the brand despite other inconsistencies.

marker_11.so_what: Both channels agree that the 'Free-From List' is the ultimate proof. Whether validated by Certifiers (Site) or The Lab (Amazon), the message is 'Purity is Truth'.

marker_12.so_what: Total strategic collapse. The site claims ownership of a Biological Condition (Hormones); Amazon claims ownership of a Technology (Glass). You are selling two completely different reasons to buy.

marker_13.so_what: The content strategy is locked on education. Both channels treat the customer as a student who needs to understand the mechanism to believe the promise.

marker_14.so_what: Both channels correctly identify the product as a 'Healer' that works on a 'Biological' level. This functional consistency creates a strong foundation for efficacy claims.

marker_15.so_what: You are creating two different emotional users. The site user is seeking 'Sanctuary' from toxins; the Amazon user is seeking 'Validation' for being smart. It splits the tribe.

marker_16.so_what: A perfect alignment on the 'Purist' identity. Buying this brand is a statement against compromise (plastic/chemicals) on both channels.

marker_17.so_what: The site frames the community as 'Insiders' (social status); Amazon frames them as 'Knowers' (intellectual status). It's a subtle but damaging rift between 'Cool' and 'Smart'.
